children.name: nasty
children.definition: /ˈnɑːstiǁˈnæsti/  someone who is nasty has a very unpleasant character and is often unkind to people:
examples: kinh tởm, thô tục, tục tỉu
▪ i’d avoid him. if i were you. he can be quite nasty.
▪ my first boss was a really nasty person, who seemed to enjoy making life difficult for everyone.
be nasty to/towards somebody đối xử thô tục với ai
▪ some of the older boys were being very nasty to him.

children.name: horrible
children.definition: /ˈhɒrɪbəl, ˈhɒrəbəlǁˈhɔː-, ˈhɑː-/  especially british behaving in a very rude, unkind, or annoying way:
examples: kinh tởm, đáng ghét
▪ her husband was a horrible man - lazy, and always drunk.
▪ i really don’t like her at all - she’s horrible!
be horrible to somebody đối xử tệ với ai
▪ i think i’ll go out if you’re just going to be horrible to me.

children.name: unpleasant
children.definition: /ʌnˈplezənt/  rude or unfriendly in the way you talk to people or answer their questions:
examples: thô thiển
▪ that man in the grocery store is always so unpleasant.
▪ did she really say that? what an unpleasant person!
be unpleasant to somebody thô thiển với ai
▪ you shouldn’t have been so unpleasant to her - she was only trying to help.

children.name: not very nice
children.definition: /nɒt veri ˈnaɪs/  especiallyspokenunkind or unfriendly - use this especially about things people say to each other:
examples: không tử tế
▪ they just told us to shut up, which wasn’t very nice.
not very nice of somebody đối xử không tử tế với ai
▪ it wasn’t very nice of him to have a party without inviting me.

children.name: mean
children.definition: /miːn/  american rude and unkind in the way you treat people:
examples: hèn hạ ,bần tiện
▪ we soon found out that our new teacher could be real mean.
be mean to somebody đối xử hèn hạ, bần tiện với ai
▪ sharon and the others were really mean to me at school today.

children.name: obnoxious
children.definition: /objectionable/əbˈnɒkʃəsǁ-ˈnɑːk-, əbˈdʒekʃənəbəl/  rude and offensive, especially deliberately objectionable is more formal than obnoxious: đáng ghét, khả ố
examples: ▪ i’d hate to be her secretary -- she’s so obnoxious.
▪ you’re behaving like a spoilt obnoxious child.
▪ i’d never have employed him if i’d realized what an objectionable person he was.
▪ what was most objectionable about her was her arrogance.

children.name: creep
children.definition: /kriːp/  informal someone who you dislike because they are unpleasant and behave in a way that makes you feel uncomfortable: sởn tóc gáy
examples: ▪ get out of here you little creep! you make me sick!
▪ he didn’t say that, did he? what a creep

children.name: nasty piece of work
children.definition: /ˌnɑːsti piːs əv ˈwɜːʳkǁˌnæsti-/  informal someone who is very unpleasant and is likely to behave in a cruel or violent way: rợn cả da gà
examples: ▪ casey and wyatt went round in a gang with don, who was a nasty piece of work.
▪ why would anyone want to kill howard, do you think?‘ ’it’s obvious. he was a nasty piece of work."

children.name: foul
children.definition: /faʊl/  a foulsmellortasteis extremely bad, and is caused especially by waste or thingsdecaying:
examples: hôi thối
▪ there was a foul smell coming up from the river.

children.name: horrible/disgusting/revolting
children.definition: /ˈhɒrɪbəl, ˈhɒrəbəlǁˈhɔː-, ˈhɑː-, dɪsˈgʌstɪŋ, rɪˈvəʊltɪŋ/  very bad - use this especially to talk about things thattaste,smell, orlookreally bad:
examples: kinh khủng, khủng khiếp
▪ it was the most disgusting meal i’ve ever eaten.
▪ he smiled showing his teeth, which were a revolting yellow colour.
▪ what a horrible smell!
▪ dick had cooked a special stew, which looked and smelled revolting.

children.name: gross
children.definition: /grəʊs/ informalvery unpleasant - use this to talk aboutfood,smells, orbehaviourthat you dislike very much:
examples: gớm giếc
▪ ooh, gross! i hate spinach!
▪ brad threw up on the floor at the party. it was really gross.

children.name: unpleasant
children.definition: /ʌnˈplezənt/  tasting or smelling horrible: khó chịu
examples: ▪ undercooked potatoes taste unpleasant and can be harmful.
▪ some animals give off an unpleasant odor that deters attackers.

children.name: not very nice
children.definition: british /not very good/not too good/nɒt veri ˈnaɪs, nɒt veri ˈgʊd, nɒt tuː ˈgʊd/  spoken a taste or smell that is not very nice or not very good is slightly unpleasant: không tốt, không ổn
examples: ▪ this cheese isn’t very good. how long have we had it?
▪ the first time i smoked a cigarette it didn’t taste very nice.
▪ i wouldn’t cook that if i were you. it doesn’t smell too good.

children.name: nasty
children.definition: /ˈnɑːstiǁˈnæsti/  tasting or smelling very strong and unpleasant: ghê tởm
examples: ▪ i’m not very keen on this wine. it has a nasty aftertaste.
▪ police were alerted when neighbors complained of a nasty smell coming from the basement.
▪ cheap perfume often smells nasty after a couple of hours.

children.name: unappetizing
children.definition: /ʌnˈæpɪtaɪzɪŋ, ʌnˈæpətaɪzɪŋ/  a meal or food that is unappetizing has an unpleasant appearance or smell and does not make you want to eat it: không ngon miệng
examples: ▪ the soup was cold and unappetizing, but it was all there was.
▪ the main course was an unappetizing leg of chicken with boiled potatoes.

children.name: nightmare
children.definition: /ˈnaɪtmeəʳ/  a very unpleasant or frighteningexperience:
examples: ác mộng
▪ we were stuck in a traffic jam for about four hours - it was a nightmare.
▪ the couple’s honeymoon turned into a nightmare when martin suddenly became very ill.
nightmare day/journey etc một ngày , cuộc hành trình ác mộng
▪ thousands of commuters faced a nightmare journey to work because of the strikes.
nightmare scenario: viễn cảnh khủng khiếp
the worst possible situation
▪ an oil spill on this part of the coast is the conservationists’ nightmare scenario.

children.name: unpleasant
children.definition: /ʌnˈplezənt/  making you feel slightly worried, uncomfortable, or embarrassed:
examples: khó chịu
▪ i had an unpleasant feeling that someone was following me.
▪ phil and jane argued the whole time, so it was a pretty unpleasant evening.
▪ then nel lost her temper and there was an extremely unpleasant scene in kenwood’s office.

children.name: nasty
children.definition: /ˈnɑːstiǁˈnæsti/  horrible - use this especially abouteventswhere there is violence, injury, or death:
examples: kinh khủng, khủng khiếp
▪ there was a nasty accident on the freeway and seven people were killed.
▪ a particularly nasty murder case
▪ the news of his death came as a very nasty shock.

children.name: not very nice
children.definition: /nɒt veri ˈnaɪs/  especiallyspokenunpleasant:
examples: không tốt lắm
▪ it’s not very nice being stuck in an elevator for an hour.
▪ divorce is not a very nice business.

children.name: horrible
children.definition: /ˈhɒrɪbəl, ˈhɒrəbəlǁˈhɔː-, ˈhɑː-/  a horribleexperienceorsituationis one that makes you feel very worried and upset:
examples: kinh khủng, khủng khiếp
▪ it was really horrible coming home and finding all our things had been stolen.
▪ there was a horrible moment when she thought she had left all her files on the train.

children.name: harsh
children.definition: /hɑːʳʃ/  a sound that is harsh is unpleasant, rough, and usually loud: khắc nghiệt, chát chúa
examples: ▪ cheap loudspeakers often produce a harsh metallic tone.
▪ ‘you’ll do what i tell you,’ he said, his voice harsh in her ear.
▪ the wind made a harsh wailing sound in the trees.

children.name: grating
children.definition: /ˈgreɪtɪŋ/  a sound that is grating is unpleasant, and is often produced by two rough things rubbing together: chói tai, ghê tai
examples: ▪ the machine began to spin faster and faster, with the grating screech of metal on metal.
▪ we could hear a group of tourists, talking in loud grating voices.
grate[intransitive verb]
▪ i can’t stand the sound of chalk grating on a blackboard.

children.name: sickening
children.definition: /ˈsɪkənɪŋ, ˈsɪknɪŋ/  a sickening sound is very unpleasant and makes you feel physically sick - use this especially about the sound when someone is badly hurt or something is badly damaged: phát bệnh, phát ôm
examples: ▪ his head hit the door with a sickening thud.
▪ there was a sickening crash and the sound of broken glass as the two trains collided.

children.name: the feeling you have when you think st is very unpleasant
disgust
children.definition: /dɪsˈgʌst, dɪz-/  kinh tởm
examples: ▪ martia gave him a look of disgust, and walked away.
▪ disgust at cruel sports has come to be a common feature of british life.
in disgustfeeling disgust cảm thấy kinh tởm
▪ she held the glass away from her in disgust. ‘what’s this awful stuff you’ve given me to drink?’

children.name: revulsion
children.definition: /rɪˈvʌlʃən/  a strong, sudden feeling of shock and disgust: sự ghê tởm đột ngột
examples: ▪ a little boy had died and, as a mother, i felt horror and revulsion.
revulsion at ghê tởm về
▪ holly was unable to hide her revulsion at what she had just read.
revulsion against ghê tởm đối với
▪ what we are now seeing is a public revulsion against violence in society.
a feeling/sense/wave of revulsion một cảm giác, cảm nhận, tràn ghê tởm
▪ news of the atrocities produced a wave of anger and revulsion.

children.name: disgusted
children.definition: /dɪsˈgʌstɪd, dɪsˈgʌstəd, dɪz-/  feeling shocked and angry at something you think is very wrong, cruel, unpleasant etc: kinh tởm, ghê tởm
examples: ▪ ann was disgusted when she saw the dirty hotel room.
▪ disgusted onlookers claimed that the man was more concerned about his car than the victims of the crash.
disgusted at kinh tởm về
▪ many people are disgusted at the continuing slaughter of dolphins.
disgusted by kinh tởm bởi
▪ he ate noisily and greedily. i tried hard not to be disgusted by his manners.
disgusted with kinh tởm với
▪ i was absolutely disgusted with the way our fans behaved.

children.name: sickened
children.definition: /ˈsɪkənd/  very shocked and angry at something such as violence or suffering: buồn nôn, muốn bệnh
examples: ▪ country vets aren’t easily sickened, but i felt my stomach turning when i saw the state of the dog.
▪ sickened detectives said the old lady was lucky to be alive after such a brutal attack.

children.name: nauseated
children.definition: /ˈnɔːzieɪtɪd, ˈnɔːzieɪtəd, -si-ǁ-zi-, -ʒi-/  if you are nauseated by something, it is so unpleasant that it makes you feel physically sick: buồn nôn,
examples: ▪ the thought of him kissing her made her feel nauseated.
▪ recognizing the dead woman’s face, she turned away, nauseated.

children.name: to seem very unpleasant to sb
disgust
children.definition: /dɪsˈgʌst, dɪz-/  ghê tởm
examples: ▪ his habit of sniffing loudly really disgusted her.
▪ the heat, the noise, the smell of the other passengers; everything about the subway disgusted him.
▪ ‘get out,’ she said. ‘you disgust me!’

children.name: revolt
children.definition: /rɪˈvəʊlt/  if something revolts you, you think it is extremely unpleasant: ghê tởm, chán ghét
examples: ▪ i opened the door and was instantly revolted by the smell.
▪ he kissed her full on the lips in a way that revolted her.

children.name: turn your stomach
children.definition: /ˌtɜːʳn jɔːʳ ˈstʌmək/  if something turns your stomach it makes you feel ill because it is so unpleasant or shocking: chán ghét, buồn nôn
examples: ▪ the sight of the dead body turned his stomach.
▪ the strike has meant piles of rotting garbage in the streets. ‘it’s enough to turn your stomach,’ said one resident.

children.name: sicken
children.definition: /ˈsɪkən/  if something such as violence or suffering sickens you, it makes you feel ill and you wish you could stop it: kinh, tởm, buồn nôn
examples: ▪ the smell of the blood sickened her and she ran out of the room.
▪ ‘some of the recent attacks on horses in this area are enough to sicken anyone,’ a police spokesman said.
